content.question:
A car company claims that its new car, the GoFast2000, has a gas mileage of 35 miles per gallon (<math alttext="m p g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow></math>). A consumer group suspects that the true mean gas mileage of the new cars is less than 35 <math alttext="miles per gallon" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow></math>. The group tests 50 randomly selected GoFast2000 cars and finds a sample mean of 34.8 <math alttext="miles per gallon" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mpg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. With all assumptions for inference met, a hypothesis test resulted in a <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value of 0.324.
For a significance level of <math alttext="alpha equals 0.05" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Î±</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.05</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, which of the following is a correct conclusion?

choices.label: The <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value is less than 0.05, and the null hypothesis is rejected. There is convincing statistical evidence that the mean is less than 35 <math alttext="miles per gallon" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mpg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value is less than 0.05, and the null hypothesis is not rejected. There is not convincing statistical evidence that the mean is less than 35 <math alttext="miles per gallon" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mpg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value is greater than 0.05, and the null hypothesis is rejected. There is not convincing statistical evidence that the mean is less than 35 <math alttext="miles per gallon" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mpg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value is greater than 0.05, and the null hypothesis is not rejected. There is convincing statistical evidence that the mean is 35 <math alttext="miles per gallon" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mpg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value is greater than 0.05, and the null hypothesis is not rejected. There is not convincing statistical evidence that the mean is less than 35 <math alttext="miles per gallon" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mpg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: The <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value is greater than 0.05, and the null hypothesis is not rejected. There is not convincing statistical evidence that the mean is less than 35 <math alttext="miles per gallon" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mpg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

topic.text: 7.5: Carrying Out a Test for a Population Mean

skill.text: Skill 4.E: Justify a claim using a decision based on significance tests.
